mil3.1.15:1.2.eng: “Venerable Nāgasena, what is the distinguishing characteristic of wisdom?”

mil3.1.15:1.4.eng: severing is a distinguishing characteristic of wisdom, and also illuminating is a distinguishing characteristic of wisdom.”

mil3.1.15:1.5.eng: “How, venerable sir, is illuminating a distinguishing characteristic of wisdom.”

mil3.1.15:1.6.pli: “Paññā, mahārāja, uppajjamānā avijjandhakāraṃ vidhameti, vijjobhāsaṃ janeti, ñāṇālokaṃ vidaṃseti, ariyasaccāni pākaṭāni karoti.
mil3.1.15:1.6.eng: “Wisdom arising, your majesty, dispels the darkness of ignorance, generates the radiance of true knowledge, displays the light of understanding, and makes evident the noble truths.

mil3.1.15:1.7.pli: Tato yogāvacaro ‘aniccan’ti vā ‘dukkhan’ti vā ‘anattā’ti vā sammappaññāya passatī”ti.
mil3.1.15:1.7.eng: Then, a spiritual practitioner sees with right wisdom what is ‘impermanent’, ‘suffering’, or ‘not self’.”

mil3.1.15:2.2.pli: “Yathā, mahārāja, puriso andhakāre gehe padīpaṃ paveseyya, paviṭṭho padīpo andhakāraṃ vidhameti, obhāsaṃ janeti, ālokaṃ vidaṃseti, rūpāni pākaṭāni karoti;
mil3.1.15:2.2.eng: “Just as, your majesty, a person might bring a lamp into a dark house, and this lamp brought in dispels the darkness, generates radiance, displays light, and makes evident forms.

mil3.1.15:2.3.pli: evameva kho, mahārāja, paññā uppajjamānā avijjandhakāraṃ vidhameti, vijjobhāsaṃ janeti, ñāṇālokaṃ vidaṃseti, ariyasaccāni pākaṭāni karoti.
mil3.1.15:2.3.eng: In the same way, your majesty, wisdom arising dispels the darkness of ignorance, generates the radiance of true knowledge, displays the light of understanding, and makes evident the noble truths.

mil3.1.15:2.4.pli: Tato yogāvacaro ‘aniccan’ti vā ‘dukkhan’ti vā ‘anattā’ti vā sammappaññāya passati.
mil3.1.15:2.4.eng: Then, a spiritual practitioner sees with right wisdom what is ‘impermanent’, ‘suffering’, or ‘not self’.

mil3.1.15:2.5.eng: Thus, your majesty, is illuminating a distinguishing characteristic of wisdom.”

mil3.1.15:4.1.eng: Distinguishing Characteristic of Wisdom Question fifteenth

mil3.1.16:0.3.eng: 16. Production of One Result from Various Mental States Question

mil3.1.16:1.2.pli: “bhante nāgasena, ime dhammā nānā santā ekaṃ atthaṃ abhinipphādentī”ti?
mil3.1.16:1.2.eng: “Venerable Nāgasena, do these mental states, though being diverse, produce the one result?”

mil3.1.16:1.3.pli: “Āma, mahārāja, ime dhammā nānā santā ekaṃ atthaṃ abhinipphādenti, kilese hanantī”ti.
mil3.1.16:1.3.eng: “Yes, your majesty, these mental states, though being diverse, do produce the one result; they kill the defilements.”

mil3.1.16:2.1.pli: “Kathaṃ, bhante, ime dhammā nānā santā ekaṃ atthaṃ abhinipphādenti, kilese hananti?
mil3.1.16:2.1.eng: “How is it, venerable sir, these mental states, though being diverse, produce the one result, and kill the defilements?

mil3.1.16:2.3.pli: “Yathā, mahārāja, senā nānā santā hatthī ca assā ca rathā ca pattī ca ekaṃ atthaṃ abhinipphādenti, saṅgāme parasenaṃ abhivijinanti;
mil3.1.16:2.3.eng: “Just as, your majesty, an army is diverse, and its elephants, horses, chariots, and foot-soldiers produce the one result; they conquer an opposing army in battle,

mil3.1.16:2.4.pli: evameva kho, mahārāja, ime dhammā nānā santā ekaṃ atthaṃ abhinipphādenti, kilese hanantī”ti.
mil3.1.16:2.4.eng: in the same way, your majesty, these mental states, though being diverse, produce the one result; they kill the defilements.”

mil3.1.16:4.1.eng: Production of One Result from Various Mental States Question sixteenth

mil3.1.2:1.1.eng: “How many rains do you have, Venerable Nāgasena?”

mil3.1.2:1.3.pli: “Ke te, bhante, satta, tvaṃ vā satta, gaṇanā vā sattā”ti?
mil3.1.2:1.3.eng: “What are these seven, venerable sir, are you the seven, or is the reckoning seven?”

mil3.1.2:2.1.pli: Tena kho pana samayena milindassa rañño sabbābharaṇapaṭimaṇḍitassa alaṅkatapaṭiyattassa pathaviyaṃ chāyā dissati, udakamaṇike ca chāyā dissati.
mil3.1.2:2.1.eng: Then, at that time, the shadow of the king adorned with all his ornaments, all decked up and prepared, appeared on the ground and is seen in a vessel of water.

mil3.1.2:2.2.pli: Atha kho āyasmā nāgaseno milindaṃ rājānaṃ etadavoca—
mil3.1.2:2.2.eng: Then Venerable Nāgasena said this to King Milinda,

mil3.1.2:2.3.pli: “ayaṃ te, mahārāja, chāyā pathaviyaṃ udakamaṇike ca dissati, kiṃ pana, mahārāja, tvaṃ vā rājā, chāyā vā rājā”ti?
mil3.1.2:2.3.eng: “This shadow appears on the ground and in the vessel of water. Are you the king, your majesty, or is the shadow the king?”

mil3.1.2:2.4.pli: “Ahaṃ, bhante nāgasena, rājā, nāyaṃ chāyā rājā, maṃ pana nissāya chāyā pavattatī”ti.
mil3.1.2:2.4.eng: “I am the king, Venerable Nāgasena, this shadow is not the king. The shadow comes into existence dependent on me.”

mil3.1.2:2.5.pli: “Evameva kho, mahārāja, vassānaṃ gaṇanā satta, na panāhaṃ satta, maṃ pana nissāya satta pavattati, chāyūpamaṃ, mahārājā”ti.
mil3.1.2:2.5.eng: “In the same way, your majesty, seven is the reckoning of rains. I am not the seven, but dependent on me seven comes into existence, similarly to your shadow, your majesty.”

mil3.1.2:2.6.pli: “Acchariyaṃ, bhante nāgasena, abbhutaṃ, bhante nāgasena, aticitrāni pañhapaṭibhānāni visajjitānī”ti.
mil3.1.2:2.6.eng: “Wonderful, Venerable Nāgasena! Marvelous, Venerable Nāgasena! Your answers to the questions asked are very brilliant!”

mil3.1.3:1.2.eng: “Venerable Nāgasena, will you converse with me?”

mil3.1.3:1.3.pli: “Sace tvaṃ, mahārāja, paṇḍitavādaṃ sallapissasi sallapissāmi, sace pana rājavādaṃ sallapissasi na sallapissāmī”ti.
mil3.1.3:1.3.eng: “If, your majesty, you will converse in the speech of wise people, I will converse, however, I will not do so if you converse like a king.”

mil3.1.3:1.4.eng: “How, Venerable Nāgasena, do wise people converse?”

mil3.1.3:1.5.pli: “Paṇḍitānaṃ kho, mahārāja, sallāpe āveṭhanampi kayirati, nibbeṭhanampi kayirati, niggahopi kayirati, paṭikammampi kayirati, vissāsopi kayirati, paṭivissāsopi kayirati, na ca tena paṇḍitā kuppanti, evaṃ kho, mahārāja, paṇḍitā sallapantī”ti.
mil3.1.3:1.5.eng: “In a conversation among wise people, your majesty, both a summing up and an unravelling are made, a refutation and a redress are made, an assertion and a counter-assertion are made, and wise people do not become angry because of that. That is the way, your majesty, wise people converse.”

mil3.1.3:1.6.eng: “Then how, venerable sir, do kings converse?”

mil3.1.3:1.7.pli: “Rājāno kho, mahārāja, sallāpe ekaṃ vatthuṃ paṭijānanti, yo taṃ vatthuṃ vilometi, tassa daṇḍaṃ āṇāpenti ‘imassa daṇḍaṃ paṇethā’ti, evaṃ kho, mahārāja, rājāno sallapantī”ti.
mil3.1.3:1.7.eng: “In a conversation, your majesty, kings assert some point of view, and for the one who disputes that view, they order punishment, saying ‘Punish that person.’ That is the way, your majesty, kings converse.”

mil3.1.3:1.8.pli: “Paṇḍitavādāhaṃ, bhante, sallapissāmi, no rājavādaṃ, vissaṭṭho bhadanto sallapatu yathā bhikkhunā vā sāmaṇerena vā upāsakena vā ārāmikena vā saddhiṃ sallapati, evaṃ vissaṭṭho bhadanto sallapatu mā bhāyatū”ti.
mil3.1.3:1.8.eng: “I will converse, venerable sir, in the speech of wise people, not in the speech of kings. May the venerable one converse freely just like he does with a bhikkhu, a novice, a lay supporter, or with a monastery attendant. May the venerable one converse freely and not be afraid.”

mil3.1.3:1.9.eng: The elder approved, saying “It is well, your majesty.”

mil3.1.3:2.4.eng: “You have been asked by me, venerable sir.”

mil3.1.3:2.6.eng: “Then, what has been answered by you, venerable sir?”

mil3.1.3:2.7.eng: “Then, what has been asked by you, your majesty?”

mil3.1.4:1.1.eng: Then, it occurred to King Milinda,

mil3.1.4:1.2.pli: “paṇḍito kho ayaṃ bhikkhu paṭibalo mayā saddhiṃ sallapituṃ, bahukāni ca me ṭhānāni pucchitabbāni bhavissanti, yāva apucchitāniyeva tāni ṭhānāni bhavissanti, atha sūriyo atthaṃ gamissati, yannūnāhaṃ sve antepure sallapeyyan”ti.
mil3.1.4:1.2.eng: “This wise bhikkhu is very competent to converse with me. There will be many matters to be asked, but there will be so many unasked and then the sun will set. Why don’t I converse with him in the inner palace tomorrow?”

mil3.1.4:2.1.eng: Then the king said to Devamantiya,

mil3.1.4:2.2.pli: “tena hi tvaṃ, devamantiya, bhadantassa āroceyyāsi ‘sve antepure raññā saddhiṃ sallāpo bhavissatī’”ti.
mil3.1.4:2.2.eng: “Well then, Devamantiya, announce this to the venerable one, ‘There will be conversation with the king in the inner palace tomorrow morning’.”

mil3.1.4:2.3.pli: Idaṃ vatvā milindo rājā uṭṭhāyāsanā theraṃ nāgasenaṃ āpucchitvā rathaṃ abhirūhitvā “nāgaseno nāgaseno”ti sajjhāyaṃ karonto pakkāmi.
mil3.1.4:2.3.eng: After he said this, King Milinda rose from his seat, having received permission from the elder Nāgasena, mounted his chariot, and left, repeating to himself, “Nāgasena, Nāgasena!”

mil3.1.4:3.1.pli: Atha kho devamantiyo āyasmantaṃ nāgasenaṃ etadavoca—
mil3.1.4:3.1.eng: Then Devamantiya said to Venerable Nāgasena,

mil3.1.4:3.3.eng: ‘There will be conversation with the king in the inner palace tomorrow morning’.”

mil3.1.4:3.4.eng: The elder approved, saying “It is well.”

mil3.1.4:3.5.pli: Atha kho tassā rattiyā accayena devamantiyo ca anantakāyo ca maṅkuro ca sabbadinno ca yena milindo rājā tenupasaṅkamiṃsu, upasaṅkamitvā rājānaṃ milindaṃ etadavocuṃ—
mil3.1.4:3.5.eng: Then, in the early morning, Devamantiya, Anantakāya, Maṅkura, and Sabbadinna approached King Milinda, and said to him,

mil3.1.4:3.8.eng: “With how many bhikkhus may he come?”

mil3.1.4:3.9.pli: “Yattake bhikkhū icchati, tattakehi bhikkhūhi saddhiṃ āgacchatū”ti.
mil3.1.4:3.9.eng: “He may come with as many bhikkhus as he likes.”

mil3.1.4:4.2.eng: “May he come with ten bhikkhus, your majesty?”

mil3.1.4:4.3.eng: For a second time, the king said,

mil3.1.4:4.4.pli: “yattake bhikkhū icchati, tattakehi bhikkhūhi saddhiṃ āgacchatū”ti.
mil3.1.4:4.4.eng: “He may come with as many bhikkhus as he likes.”

mil3.1.4:4.5.eng: For a second time, Sabbadinna said,

mil3.1.4:4.6.eng: “May he come with ten bhikkhus, your majesty?”

mil3.1.4:4.7.eng: For a third time, the king said,

mil3.1.4:4.8.pli: “yattake bhikkhū icchati, tattakehi bhikkhūhi saddhiṃ āgacchatū”ti.
mil3.1.4:4.8.eng: “He may come with as many bhikkhus as he likes.”

mil3.1.4:4.9.eng: For a third time, Sabbadinna said,

mil3.1.4:4.10.eng: “May he come with ten bhikkhus, your majesty?”

mil3.1.4:4.11.pli: “Sabbo panāyaṃ sakkāro paṭiyādito, ahaṃ bhaṇāmi ‘yattake bhikkhū icchati, tattakehi bhikkhūhi saddhiṃ āgacchatū’ti.
mil3.1.4:4.11.eng: “All this hospitality has been prepared. I say, ‘He may come with as many bhikkhus as he likes.’

mil3.1.4:4.12.pli: Ayaṃ bhaṇe sabbadinno aññathā bhaṇati, kiṃ nu mayaṃ nappaṭibalā bhikkhūnaṃ bhojanaṃ dātun”ti?
mil3.1.4:4.12.eng: I say this and Sabbadinna says otherwise! Are we not competent to give food to the bhikkhus?”

mil3.1.4:4.13.eng: When this was said, Sabbadinna was ashamed.

mil3.1.4:5.1.pli: Atha kho devamantiyo ca anantakāyo ca maṅkuro ca yenāyasmā nāgaseno tenupasaṅkamiṃsu, upasaṅkamitvā āyasmantaṃ nāgasenaṃ etadavocuṃ—
mil3.1.4:5.1.eng: Then, Devamantiya, Anantakāya, and Maṅkura, approached Venerable Nāgasena, and said to him,

mil3.1.4:5.3.pli: ‘yattake bhikkhū icchati, tattakehi bhikkhūhi saddhiṃ āgacchatū’”ti.
mil3.1.4:5.3.eng: ‘You may come with as many bhikkhus as you like.’”

mil3.1.4:5.4.pli: Atha kho āyasmā nāgaseno pubbaṇhasamayaṃ nivāsetvā pattacīvaramādāya asītiyā bhikkhusahassehi saddhiṃ sāgalaṃ pāvisi.
mil3.1.4:5.4.eng: Then, in the morning, Venerable Nāgasena arose, got dressed, took his bowl and robe, and entered Sāgala with eighty thousand bhikkhus.

mil3.1.4:6.1.pli: Atha kho anantakāyo āyasmantaṃ nāgasenaṃ nissāya gacchanto āyasmantaṃ nāgasenaṃ etadavoca—
mil3.1.4:6.1.eng: Now, Anantakāya walking alongside Venerable Nāgasena said to him,

mil3.1.4:6.2.pli: “bhante nāgasena, yaṃ panetaṃ brūsi ‘nāgaseno’ti, katamo ettha nāgaseno”ti?
mil3.1.4:6.2.eng: “Venerable Nāgasena, that which you call ‘Nāgasena’, what here is Nāgasena?”

mil3.1.4:6.4.eng: “Who do you think here is Nāgasena?”

mil3.1.4:6.5.pli: “Yo so, bhante, abbhantare vāto jīvo pavisati ca nikkhamati ca, so ‘nāgaseno’ti maññāmī”ti.
mil3.1.4:6.5.eng: “The breath within, the life force, which goes in and comes out, that I consider ‘Nāgasena’.”

mil3.1.4:6.6.pli: “Yadi paneso vāto nikkhamitvā nappaviseyya, pavisitvā na nikkhameyya, jīveyya nu kho so puriso”ti?
mil3.1.4:6.6.eng: “When, then, the breath goes out and does not come in, or it comes in and doesn’t go out, would that man live?”

mil3.1.4:6.8.pli: “Ye panime saṅkhadhamakā saṅkhaṃ dhamenti, tesaṃ vāto puna pavisatī”ti?
mil3.1.4:6.8.eng: “Then, when those conch blowers sound the conch, does their breath re-enter?”

mil3.1.4:6.10.pli: “Ye panime vaṃsadhamakā vaṃsaṃ dhamenti, tesaṃ vāto puna pavisatī”ti?
mil3.1.4:6.10.eng: “Then when those bamboo flute blowers sound the flute, does their breath re-enter?”

mil3.1.4:6.12.pli: “Ye panime siṅgadhamakā siṅgaṃ dhamenti, tesaṃ vāto puna pavisatī”ti?
mil3.1.4:6.12.eng: “Then, when those horn blowers sound the horn, does their breath re-enter?”

mil3.1.4:6.14.eng: “Why, then, do they not die because of that?”

mil3.1.4:6.15.pli: “Nāhaṃ paṭibalo tayā vādinā saddhiṃ sallapituṃ, sādhu, bhante, atthaṃ jappehī”ti.
mil3.1.4:6.15.eng: “I am not competent to converse with you, a debater of the doctrine. It would be good, venerable sir, if you told me the meaning.”

mil3.1.4:6.16.pli: “Neso jīvo, assāsapassāsā nāmete kāyasaṅkhārā”ti thero abhidhammakathaṃ kathesi.
mil3.1.4:6.16.eng: “It is not the life force, in-breathing and out-breathing are just bodily activities.” The elder gave a talk on Abhidhamma.

mil3.1.4:6.17.eng: Then, Anantakāya announced that he was a lay follower.

mil3.1.5:1.1.pli: Atha kho āyasmā nāgaseno yena milindassa rañño nivesanaṃ tenupasaṅkami, upasaṅkamitvā paññatte āsane nisīdi.
mil3.1.5:1.1.eng: Then Venerable Nāgasena approached King Milinda’s dwelling, and on arriving sat on the seat prepared.

mil3.1.5:1.2.pli: Atha kho milindo rājā āyasmantaṃ nāgasenaṃ saparisaṃ paṇītena khādanīyena bhojanīyena sahatthā santappetvā sampavāretvā ekamekaṃ bhikkhuṃ ekamekena dussayugena acchādetvā āyasmantaṃ nāgasenaṃ ticīvarena acchādetvā āyasmantaṃ nāgasenaṃ etadavoca—
mil3.1.5:1.2.eng: King Milinda then served and satisfied with his own hands Venerable Nāgasena and his assembly with delicious hard and soft foods, presented to each bhikkhu a pair of cloths, and to Venerable Nāgasena a set of three robes. He said to Venerable Nāgasena,

mil3.1.5:1.3.pli: “bhante nāgasena, dasahi, bhikkhūhi saddhiṃ idha nisīdatha, avasesā gacchantū”ti.
mil3.1.5:1.3.eng: “Venerable Nāgasena, sit here with ten bhikkhus and let the rest of them go.”

mil3.1.5:2.1.pli: Atha kho milindo rājā āyasmantaṃ nāgasenaṃ bhuttāviṃ onītapattapāṇiṃ viditvā aññataraṃ nīcaṃ āsanaṃ gahetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi, ekamantaṃ nisinno kho milindo rājā āyasmantaṃ nāgasenaṃ etadavoca—
mil3.1.5:2.1.eng: Then King Milinda, having seen that Venerable Nāgasena had eaten, and had withdrawn his hand from his bowl, took a certain low seat and sat down on one side. Seated there, King Milinda said to Venerable Nāgasena,

mil3.1.5:2.2.eng: “What is the conversation to be about, Venerable Nāgasena?”

mil3.1.5:2.3.pli: “Atthena mayaṃ, mahārāja, atthikā, atthe hotu kathāsallāpo”ti.
mil3.1.5:2.3.eng: “We need a goal, your majesty. Let the conversation be about the goal.”

mil3.1.5:3.2.pli: “kimatthiyā, bhante nāgasena, tumhākaṃ pabbajjā, ko ca tumhākaṃ paramattho”ti.
mil3.1.5:3.2.eng: “What use for you, Venerable Nāgasena, is your going forth? What is the ultimate goal for you?”

mil3.1.5:3.4.pli: “kinti, mahārāja, idaṃ dukkhaṃ nirujjheyya, aññañca dukkhaṃ na uppajjeyyāti.
mil3.1.5:3.4.eng: “How then, your majesty, would this suffering cease, and other suffering not arise?

mil3.1.5:3.5.pli: Etadatthā, mahārāja, amhākaṃ pabbajjā, anupādā parinibbānaṃ kho pana amhākaṃ paramattho”ti.
mil3.1.5:3.5.eng: This, your majesty, is the purpose of our going forth, and our ultimate goal is final nibbāna without any clinging.”

mil3.1.5:4.1.pli: “Kiṃ pana, bhante nāgasena, sabbe etadatthāya pabbajantī”ti?
mil3.1.5:4.1.eng: “Do all go forth for this goal, Venerable Nāgasena?”

mil3.1.5:4.2.pli: “Na hi, mahārāja, keci etadatthāya pabbajanti, keci rājābhinītā pabbajanti, keci corābhinītā pabbajanti, keci iṇaṭṭā pabbajanti, keci ājīvikatthāya pabbajanti, ye pana sammā pabbajanti, te etadatthāya pabbajantī”ti.
mil3.1.5:4.2.eng: “Certainly not, your majesty, some go forth through fear of kings, some go forth through fear of thieves, some go forth oppressed by debts, and others go forth for the sake of livelihood. But those who go forth the right way, go forth for such a goal.”

mil3.1.5:5.1.eng: “Did you go forth for this goal, venerable sir?”

mil3.1.5:5.2.pli: “Ahaṃ kho, mahārāja, daharako santo pabbajito, na jānāmi imassa nāmatthāya pabbajāmīti, api ca kho me evaṃ ahosi ‘paṇḍitā ime samaṇā sakyaputtiyā, te maṃ sikkhāpessantī’ti, svāhaṃ tehi sikkhāpito jānāmi ca passāmi ca ‘imassa nāmatthāya pabbajjā’”ti.
mil3.1.5:5.2.eng: “I went forth, your majesty, when I was a child and I did not know that I was going forth for this goal. Then, it occurred to me, ‘These recluses, Sakyan sons, are wise and they will train me. Now, I have been trained by them, and I know and see that the going forth is for that goal.’”

mil3.1.6:1.2.pli: “bhante nāgasena, atthi koci mato na paṭisandahatī”ti.
mil3.1.6:1.2.eng: “Is there anyone who has died, Venerable Nāgasena, who is not reconnected?”

mil3.1.6:1.4.eng: “There are some who reconnect and some who don’t reconnect.”

mil3.1.6:1.6.eng: “One with defilements reconnects and one without defilements doesn’t reconnect.”

mil3.1.6:1.8.pli: “Sace, mahārāja, saupādāno bhavissāmi paṭisandahissāmi, sace anupādāno bhavissāmi na paṭisandahissāmī”ti.
mil3.1.6:1.8.eng: “If, your majesty, I am with clinging I will reconnect, and if I am without clinging I will not.”

mil3.1.7:1.2.pli: “bhante nāgasena, yo na paṭisandahati, nanu so yoniso manasikārena na paṭisandahatī”ti?
mil3.1.7:1.2.eng: “Is it not, Venerable Nāgasena, that the one who does not reconnect does not do so because of careful attention?”

mil3.1.7:1.3.pli: “Yoniso ca, mahārāja, manasikārena paññāya ca aññehi ca kusalehi dhammehī”ti.
mil3.1.7:1.3.eng: “It is because of careful attention, your majesty, and because of wisdom and other wholesome mental states.”

mil3.1.7:1.4.eng: “Is careful attention, venerable sir, the same as wisdom?”

mil3.1.7:1.5.pli: “Na hi, mahārāja, añño manasikāro, aññā paññā, imesaṃ kho, mahārāja, ajeḷakagoṇamahiṃsaoṭṭhagadrabhānampi manasikāro atthi, paññā pana tesaṃ natthī”ti.
mil3.1.7:1.5.eng: “Certainly not, your majesty, careful attention is one thing, wisdom is another. Goats, rams, bulls, buffalos, camels, and donkeys also have careful attention, but they do not have wisdom.”

mil3.1.8:1.2.eng: “Venerable Nāgasena, what is the distinguishing characteristic of attention, and what is the distinguishing characteristic of wisdom?”

mil3.1.8:1.3.eng: “Examination is the distinguishing characteristic of attention, and severing is the distinguishing characteristic of wisdom.”

mil3.1.8:2.1.eng: “How does attention have the distinguishing characteristic of examination? And how does wisdom have the distinguishing characteristic of severing?

mil3.1.8:2.3.eng: “Do you know barley reapers, your majesty?”

mil3.1.8:2.5.eng: “How, your majesty, do barley reapers reap barley?”

mil3.1.8:2.6.pli: “Vāmena, bhante, hatthena yavakalāpaṃ gahetvā dakkhiṇena hatthena dāttaṃ gahetvā dāttena chindantī”ti.
mil3.1.8:2.6.eng: “Venerable sir, they take a sheaf of barley in the left hand, and take a sickle in the right hand, and they cut with the sickle.”

mil3.1.8:3.1.pli: “Yathā, mahārāja, yavalāvako vāmena hatthena yavakalāpaṃ gahetvā dakkhiṇena hatthena dāttaṃ gahetvā yavaṃ chindati;
mil3.1.8:3.1.eng: “Just as, your majesty, a barley reaper takes a sheaf of barley in the left hand, takes a sickle in the right hand, and cuts the barley,

mil3.1.8:3.2.pli: evameva kho, mahārāja, yogāvacaro manasikārena mānasaṃ gahetvā paññāya kilese chindati, evaṃ kho, mahārāja, ūhanalakkhaṇo manasikāro, evaṃ chedanalakkhaṇā paññā”ti.
mil3.1.8:3.2.eng: in the same way, your majesty, does the spiritual aspirant take hold of the mind with attention, and cut off the defilements with wisdom. Indeed thus, your majesty, examination is the distinguishing characteristic of attention, and severing is the distinguishing characteristic of wisdom.”

mil3.1.8:5.1.eng: Distinguishing Characteristic of Attention Question eighth

mil3.1.9:1.2.pli: “bhante nāgasena, yaṃ panetaṃ brūsi ‘aññehi ca kusalehi dhammehī’ti, katame te kusalā dhammā”ti?
mil3.1.9:1.2.eng: “Venerable Nāgasena, that which you called ‘and other wholesome mental states’, what are these wholesome mental states?”

mil3.1.9:1.3.pli: “Sīlaṃ, mahārāja, saddhā vīriyaṃ sati samādhi, ime te kusalā dhammā”ti.
mil3.1.9:1.3.eng: “Virtue, your majesty, faith, energy, mindfulness, and concentration; these are those wholesome mental states.”

mil3.1.9:1.4.eng: “What, venerable sir, is the distinguishing characteristic of virtue?”

mil3.1.9:1.5.pli: “Patiṭṭhānalakkhaṇaṃ, mahārāja, sīlaṃ sabbesaṃ kusalānaṃ dhammānaṃ, indriyabalabojjhaṅgamaggaṅgasatipaṭṭhānasammappadhānaiddhipādajhānavimokkhasamādhisamāpattīnaṃ sīlaṃ patiṭṭhaṃ, sīle patiṭṭhito kho, mahārāja, yogāvacaro sīlaṃ nissāya sīle patiṭṭhāya pañcindriyāni bhāveti saddhindriyaṃ vīriyindriyaṃ satindriyaṃ samādhindriyaṃ paññindriyanti, sabbe kusalā dhammā na parihāyantī”ti.
mil3.1.9:1.5.eng: “Virtue, your majesty, has the distinguishing characteristic of being the ground for all wholesome mental states.  Virtue is the ground for the faculties, the powers, the enlightenment factors, the path factors, the establishments of mindfulness, the right efforts, the bases of psychic power, meditation, emancipation, concentration, and the attainments. A spiritual aspirant, your majesty, dependent on virtue, grounded in virtue, develops the five faculties of faith, energy, mindfulness, concentration, and wisdom. None of these wholesome mental states decrease.”

mil3.1.9:2.2.pli: “Yathā, mahārāja, ye keci bījagāmabhūtagāmā vuḍḍhiṃ virūḷhiṃ vepullaṃ āpajjanti, sabbe te pathaviṃ nissāya pathaviyaṃ patiṭṭhāya vuḍḍhiṃ virūḷhiṃ vepullaṃ āpajjanti;
mil3.1.9:2.2.eng: “Just as, your majesty, whatever seeds and plants attain to growth, development, and abundance, do so in dependence on the earth, and grounded by the earth.

mil3.1.9:2.3.pli: evameva kho, mahārāja, yogāvacaro sīlaṃ nissāya sīle patiṭṭhāya pañcindriyāni bhāveti saddhindriyaṃ vīriyindriyaṃ satindriyaṃ samādhindriyaṃ paññindriyan”ti.
mil3.1.9:2.3.eng: In the same way, a spiritual aspirant, your majesty, dependent on virtue, grounded in virtue, develops the five faculties of faith, energy, mindfulness, concentration, and wisdom.”

mil3.1.9:3.2.pli: “Yathā, mahārāja, ye keci balakaraṇīyā kammantā kayiranti, sabbe te pathaviṃ nissāya pathaviyaṃ patiṭṭhāya kayiranti;
mil3.1.9:3.2.eng: “Just as, your majesty, whatever actions are to be done with strength, all of these are done in dependence on the earth, and grounded by the earth.

mil3.1.9:3.3.pli: evameva kho, mahārāja, yogāvacaro sīlaṃ nissāya sīle patiṭṭhāya pañcindriyāni bhāveti saddhindriyaṃ vīriyindriyaṃ satindriyaṃ samādhindriyaṃ paññindriyan”ti.
mil3.1.9:3.3.eng: In the same way, a spiritual aspirant, your majesty, dependent on virtue, grounded in virtue, develops the five faculties of faith, energy, mindfulness, concentration, and wisdom.”

mil3.1.9:4.2.pli: “Yathā, mahārāja, nagaravaḍḍhakī nagaraṃ māpetukāmo paṭhamaṃ nagaraṭṭhānaṃ sodhāpetvā khāṇukaṇṭakaṃ apakaḍḍhāpetvā bhūmiṃ samaṃ kārāpetvā tato aparabhāge vīthicatukkasiṅghāṭakādiparicchedena vibhajitvā nagaraṃ māpeti;
mil3.1.9:4.2.eng: “Just as, your majesty, a city architect, desiring to build a city, would first clear a site for the city, remove the trees and stumps, make the ground even, and there at a future time, divide it up into streets and four-way crossroads, and build the city.

mil3.1.9:4.3.pli: evameva kho, mahārāja, yogāvacaro sīlaṃ nissāya sīle patiṭṭhāya pañcindriyāni bhāveti saddhindriyaṃ vīriyindriyaṃ satindriyaṃ samādhindriyaṃ paññindriyan”ti.
mil3.1.9:4.3.eng: In the same way, a spiritual aspirant, your majesty, dependent on virtue, grounded in virtue, develops the five faculties of faith, energy, mindfulness, concentration, and wisdom.”

mil3.1.9:5.2.pli: “Yathā, mahārāja, laṅghako sippaṃ dassetukāmo pathaviṃ khaṇāpetvā sakkharakathalaṃ apakaḍḍhāpetvā bhūmiṃ samaṃ kārāpetvā mudukāya bhūmiyā sippaṃ dasseti;
mil3.1.9:5.2.eng: “Just as, your majesty, an acrobat, desiring to display their craft, would dig the earth, remove the gravel and stones, make the ground even, and thus display their craft on soft earth.

mil3.1.9:5.3.pli: evameva kho, mahārāja, yogāvacaro sīlaṃ nissāya sīle patiṭṭhāya pañcindriyāni bhāveti saddhindriyaṃ vīriyindriyaṃ satindriyaṃ samādhindriyaṃ paññindriyanti.
mil3.1.9:5.3.eng: In the same way, a spiritual aspirant, your majesty, dependent on virtue, grounded in virtue, develops the five faculties of faith, energy, mindfulness, concentration, and wisdom.

mil3.1.9:5.4.eng: And this too was said, your majesty, by the Blessed One:

mil3.1.9:7.1.eng: This is the support, as the earth is for living beings.

mil3.1.9:7.2.eng: And this is the root for growth in wholesome qualities.

mil3.1.9:7.3.eng: It is the starting point for all the Conqueror’s teachings.

mil3.1.9:7.4.eng: This collection of virtue is supremely binding.’”

mil3.1.9:9.1.eng: Distinguishing Characteristic of Virtue Question ninth
